questions.text: Which of the following best describes the bony Bankart lesion?

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim
Stripping of the antero-inferior glenoid labrum
Rupture of inferior glenohumeral ligament complex

questions.solution:
The bony bankart lesion is a small, avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim.

During an anterior shoulder dislocation, the head of the humerus can tear the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum. This is known as Bankart lesion. In some cases, a small fragment of bone from the glenoid rim can also get avulsed. This is known as a bony Bankart lesion.

Avulsion of posterior capsular periosteum is seen in reverse Bankart lesion.

questions.text: What is the pathology seen in patients with Trevor's disease?
questions.solution:
Trevor's disease is characterized by the presence of intra-articular epiphyseal osteochondromas. 

In Trevor's disease, bony lesions appear on the medial or lateral aspect of the epiphysis. The lesions are localized to a single side of the body. Knee and ankle are most frequently involved.

Multiple osteochondromas are seen in a condition known as diaphyseal aclasis or multiple hereditary exostoses.

The below lateral view X-ray of the lower limb shows non-uniform bone growth, and unconnected ossification centers related to the epiphyses at the knee and ankle. This is seen in Trevor's disease.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement regarding chondromalacia patella ______

choices.text: There is increasing osteoporosis of the patella
There is blistering in the patellar cartilage
It affects the medial facet of the patella
It is commonly associated with vastus medius tendinitis

questions.solution:
• Chondromalacia patella is defined as a blistering cystic change in the patellar cartilage usually affecting the medial facet of the patella. It is associated with vastus medius tendinitis.
  • The change is attributed to a decrease in sulfated mucopolysaccharide in the ground substance.

questions.text: Which of the statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image given below.

choices.text: ORIF is done to prevent this deformity
Increased risk of tardy ulnar nerve palsy
Baumann’s angle is greater than 80 degrees in this child
Brachial artery is injured in fractures that lead to this deformity

questions.solution:
The deformity seen is a cubitus varus (gunstock) deformity.  There is no risk of ulnar nerve palsy in this deformity.

Normal Baumann’s angle is <80 degrees. If >80 degrees, it suggests a varus displacement and possibly a supracondylar fracture.

Brachial artery, median and radial nerve are some of the commonest structures to be injured in case of a supracondylar fracture.

Closed reduction is unlikely to be stable and K-wire fixation is not strong enough to permit early mobilization. 

Open reduction and internal fixation is therefore the treatment of choice.

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a chronic clinical condition characterized by a delayed onset ulnar neuropathy after an injury to the elbow. Typically, tardy ulnar nerve palsy occurs as a consequence of nonunion of pediatric lateral condyle fractures at the elbow, which eventually lead to a cubitus valgus deformity

questions.text: Notta’s nodule is the stenosing tenovaginitis of ____?
questions.solution:
Notta’s nodule is a palpable thickening of the tendon following stenosing tenovaginitis of flexor pollicis longus at the level of the 1st Annular pulley over the MCP joint leading to a congenital trigger finger.

It occurs within a few months after birth. Triggering often resolves spontaneously but, if the condition persists, it can be treated surgically.

questions.text: How much is ‘X’ if the radiograph given below is of a normal foot?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows Kite’s (Talocalcaneal) angle, which is normally 20-40 degrees.

In an anterior-posterior film, lines can be drawn through the long axis of the talus parallel to its medial border and through that of the calcaneum parallel to its lateral border; they normally cross at an angle of 20–40 degrees (Kite’s angle) but in club foot the two lines may be almost parallel.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding Parsonage Turner syndrome?

choices.text: One of the risk factors is immunization
Variants can present with cranial nerve neuropathies
Causes acute shoulder pain and muscle wasting

questions.solution:
Neck movements are relatively pain free with Parsonage turner syndrome (Brachial neuritis).

It is a rare syndrome affecting mainly the lower motor neurons of the brachial plexus and/or individual nerves or nerve branches.

It is characterized by the acute onset of excruciating unilateral shoulder pain, followed by flaccid paralysis of shoulder and parascapular muscles several days later.

The syndrome can also involve cranial nerves.

questions.text: A subperiosteally placed graft is called:
questions.solution:
A phemister bone graft is placed subperiosteally and is most commonly used in the tibial injuries.

Other options:

  • A cancellous bone graft is useful in defects less than 2.5 cm. it is rapidly revascularised.
  • A cortical bone graft provides fixation and osteogenesis. It can be used for the non union of shafts of long bones.

questions.text: A scaphoid fracture is bridged using the following screw. Identify the screw
questions.solution:
This is a Herbert screw, which is cannulated and threaded at both ends. It is designed for use in fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid. The proximal portion has a wider pitch to its thread. This screw is used where a standard screw would impinge on adjacent tissues.

The Acutrak screw is also used for the treatment of most scaphoid fractures.  It is a cannulated, headless and fully threaded screw.

The interference screw is a direct tendon-to-bone interference fixation device.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about FGF23 (Fibroblast Growth Factor 23)?

choices.text: It promotes rise of serum calcium
Elevated FGF23 levels are seen in hypophosphataemic rickets
It promotes the excretion of ionised phosphate
Increased FGF23 levels are seen in familial tumoural calcinosis

questions.solution:
In familial tumoural calcinosis, decreased FGF23 levels are seen, in which hyperphosphataemia occurs, leading to soft-tissue calcification.

The main function of FGF23 is regulation of phosphate concentration in plasma.

FGF23

  • Promotes excretion of phosphate by supressing tubular reabsorption
  • Promotes rise of Serum calcium 
  • Is elevated in hypophosphatemic rickets

questions.text: Which of the following would not be beneficial for the treatment of pulmonary metastasis of a giant cell tumour?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin is not the preferred treatment of pulmonary metastasis of a giant cell tumour.

In patients with pulmonary metastases,

  • Resection should be attempted.
  • Chemotherapy has limited success
  • Irradiation should be reserved for symptomatic inoperable lesions.

Denosumab(chemotherapy) has been approved for use in

  • Skeletally mature patients who have an unresectable giant cell tumour.
  • Where surgical resection would result in severe morbidity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about autologous bone grafts?

choices.text: Proximal part of the tibia is the most common site for bone graft harvest
A temporary polymethylmethacrylate cement spacer delays the grafting process
Cortical grafts are more rapidly incorporated than cancellous grafts
Vascularised grafts are the ideal grafts

questions.solution:
Vascularised grafts are theoretically the ideal graft; bone is transferred complete with its blood supply, which is anastomosed to vessels at the recipient site.

But the technique is difficult and time-consuming.

Available donor sites include the

  • iliac crest (complete with one of the circumflex arteries),
  • the fibula (with the peroneal artery),
  • radial shaft

The iliac crest remains the most frequently used site for bone-graft harvest.

A temporary polymethylmethacrylate cement spacer creates a bone friendly environment.

Cancellous grafts are more rapidly incorporated into host bone than cortical grafts, but Cortical bone has greater strength and structural integrity.

questions.text: The radial nerve is injured in front of the lateral epicondyle. Which of the following will not occur?
questions.solution:
Before radial nerve reaches the lateral condyle, it supplies the extensor carpi radialis longus muscle. Hence, wrist drop is not present when the nerve is injured at the lateral condyle.

Before it crosses the elbow, in front of the lateral condyle, it divides into two branches, superficial and deep. 

The superficial branch is primarily sensory and travels alongside the radial artery into the forearm. This accounts for the sensory loss.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department following a RTA. You notice severe facial bruising and on examination his muscles are flaccid, his reflexes and sensations are absent over all four limbs. What is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Log rolling should be done to check for injuries
Suspected hyperextension injury of cervical spine
A complete spinal cord lesion has occurred
Quadruple immobilization should be carried out immediately

questions.solution:
The patient is in spinal shock and a complete spinal cord lesion cannot be diagnosed as the neurological outcome may improve.

The patient is ‘log- rolled’ (i.e. turned over ‘in one piece’) to avoid movement of the vertebral column.

With severe facial bruising, always suspect a hyperextension injury of the neck.

Similarly bruising over the lower back should raise the suspicion of a lumbar vertebral fracture.

Quadruple immobilization should be carried out immediately. The patient is on a backboard, the head supported by sandbags and held with tape across the forehead, and with a semi-rigid collar.

Note : Priapism is an important finding since it occurs almost immediately with ‘complete’ cord injuries and settles in a few hours.

questions.text: An axial compression force type of injury to the spine could result in which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Axial compression force results in load compression and an explosive comminuted fracture of the C5 vertebra. CT is required for all patients to evaluate the extent of injury. Treatment includes Rigid Immobilization Surgery.

Fracture of the pedicle and the transverse process are results of a lateral flexion force. Flexion Rotation Force leads to disruption of facet capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Q-angle?

choices.text: It is about 14 degrees in men
One of the lines forming the angle is a line from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tibial tubercle
It is about 20 degrees in women
Decreased Q-angle is a predisposing factor for chondromalacia

questions.solution:
Q-angle (quadriceps angle) is about 14 degrees in men and 17 degrees in women.

This is the angle subtended by a line drawn from the anterior superior iliac spine to the centre of the patella and another from the centre of the patella to the tibial tubercle.

An increased Q-angle is regarded as a predisposing factor in the development of chondromalacia.

questions.text: Which NSAID is not effective in acute gout?
questions.solution:
All NSAIDs are almost equally efficacious except Tolmetin, which is not effective in cases of acute gout.

  • The most effective drugs are any of those with a short half-life and include
    • Indomethacin
    • Naproxen
    • Ibuprofen
    • Celecoxib
  • Oxaprozin lowers serum uric acid levels.

questions.text: The Erlenmeyer flask appearance seen in this x ray is typically seen in?
questions.solution:
The is appearance is seen in a lot of conditions, including Gaucher’s disease.
It is not seen in the other conditions listed above.

Erlenmeyer flask deformity (EFD) (also known as metaphyseal flaring) is a radiographic appearance typically on a femoral radiograph demonstrating relative constriction of the diaphysis and flaring of the metaphysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about articular cartilage?

choices.text: Similar cartilage is also found in intervertebral discs
It is made up of hyaline cartilage

questions.solution:
Articular cartilage is made up of hyaline cartilage.

  • The components of articular cartilage
    • Hyaline cartilage
    • Glycosaminoglycans : Chondroitin sulfate and keratan sulfate
    • Type 2 Collagen
    • Chondrocytes

Option a : Fibrous cartilage is present in intervertebral discs.

Option c : Type 2 collagen is mainly responsible for the tensile strength of the cartilage.

Option d : Articular cartilage is aneural and hence it is insensitive to pain.

questions.text: Which part of the clavicle is most commonly fractured?
questions.solution:
The middle third of the clavicle is most commonly fractured. 

The middle third of the clavicle is narrowest and has the least amount of surrounding soft tissue structures. Therefore, 80% of fractures are seen in this area.

Within the middle-third of the clavicle, the junction of the medial 3/5th and the lateral 2/5th has been described to be the weakest point. Lateral third fractures are the second most common type of clavicular fractures.

Fall on the shoulder (direct impact) and fall on the outstretched hand are the most common causes of clavicle fracture.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about the double crush phenomenon?
1: Distal compression of a peripheral nerve renders it more susceptible to the effects of a second, more proximal injury.
2: Peripheral nerve entrapments are often associated with cervical or lumbar spondylosis.
questions.solution:
Peripheral nerve entrapments are often associated with cervical or lumbar spondylosis.

The double crush phenomenon is that proximal compression of a peripheral nerve renders it more susceptible to the effects of a second, more peripheral injury.

questions.text: All are tumor-like lesions except _______.
questions.solution:
Aneurysmal bone cyst, eosinophilic granuloma, and monostotic fibrous dysplasia are tumour-like lesions. Enchondroma falls under the category of cartilage forming tumors. 

WHO classification of bone tumors:

  • Bone forming tumors
  • Cartilage forming tumors
  • Giant cell tumors
  • Marrow tumors
  • Vascular tumors
  • Tumor-like lesions

Tumor-like lesions:

  • Simple and aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Fibrous dysplasia (Mono and polyostotic)
  • Reparative giant cell granuloma
  • Fibrous cortical defect
  • Eosinophilic granuloma

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dynamic stabilizer of the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Iliopsoas muscle is a dynamic stabilizer of the hip joint.

Dynamic stabilizers: 

  • Iliopsoas anteriorly
  • Short external rotators posteriorly
  • Hip abductors laterally.

 Static stabilizers:

  • Iliofemoral ligament
  • Pubofemoral ligament
  • Ischiofemoral ligament
  • The joint capsule and labrum

questions.text: The condition that may result in secondary osteosarcoma is _______
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, only Paget’s disease can progress to secondary osteosarcoma.

Other conditions which can progress to secondary osteosarcoma:

  • Paget's disease
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Post-radiation
  • Bone infarction
  • Survivors of retinoblastoma
  • Multiple osteochondromas
  • Chronic osteomyelitis 
  • Melorheostosis
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: The oblique spinal X-ray of a patient having chronic low-back ache is given below.  What is the sign seen here called?
questions.solution:
In the X-ray given, there is a break in the pars interarticularlis of the L4 vertebra, which appears like a beheaded Scottish terrier. Hence, it is known as beheaded Scottish terrier sign and it is diagnostic of spondylolisthesis. 

The investigation of choice in the case of spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis is an oblique view X-ray of the lumbar spine.

Normally, the posterior elements of the normal vertebra appear like a 'Scottish terrier dog' and this is known as Scottie dog sign. 

The X-ray spine below shows Scottie dog sign and beheaded Scottish terrier sign.

In spondylolysis, there is a defect or break in the pars without dislocation. This gives the appearance of Scottish terrier with collar sign as shown in the image below.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about inter-vertebral discs?

A. Accomodates weight and shock B. Highly vascular structure C. Major constitute of disc is water D. The central part of disc is derived from ectoderm
questions.solution:
An intervertebral disc has a central nucleus pulposus, which is a remnant of the notochord (mesoderm) and annulus fibrosus at the periphery. It binds the vertebra together, allows motion, absorbs shock, distributes load between the segments, and contributes to lordosis.

The discs are the largest avascular structures in the body and depend on diffusion from a specialized network of end plate blood vessels for nutrition.

questions.text: What is primary impingement?

choices.text: Impingement occurring beneath the coracoacromial arch
Seen in overhead athletes like throwers and swimmers

questions.solution:
Primary impingement occurs beneath the coracoacromial arch. 

There are three types of impingement syndrome.

  • Primary impingement is due to structural changes that mechanically narrow the subacromial space. It occurs beneath the coracoacromial arch and is due to subacromial overloading. It is the most common.
  • Secondary impingement results from a functional disturbance of the humeral head. It is due to a relative decrease in the subacromial arch and is due to micro-instability of the glenohumeral joint or scapulothoracic instability.
  • Posterior or internal impingement is seen in overhead athletes like swimmers and throwers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Forestier’s disease?

choices.text: Asymmetrical intervertebral spur formation and bridging seen

questions.solution:
Pain and stiffness are rarely severe in diffuse idiopathic hyperostosis or Forestier’s disease.

This is a common disorder with widespread ossification of ligaments and tendon insertions.

X-rays show asymmetrical intervertebral spur formation and bridging throughout the dorsolumbar spine. It bears a resemblance to AS, but it is not an inflammatory disease. The sacroiliac joints are not eroded and the ESR is normal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic woman noticed an audible click every time she flexed her left middle finger. The extension of the middle finger is as depicted in the clip below. This is caused due to involvement of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the video showing the middle finger in the flexed position requiring extra force to extend it is suggestive of a trigger finger. 

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley.

A1 pulley is an annular ligament that acts as a belt that straps the flexor tendon to the underlying phalanges. There are 5 annular ligaments in each finger namely A1. A2, A3, A4, and A5.

The image given below is showing the nodule in the flexor tendon and the 5 annular ligaments of the finger.

When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed. 

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A wounds > 10cm long, with extensive soft tissue damage and a comminuted fracture underneath with adequate periosteal covering fall under which class of Gustilo’s classification?
questions.solution:
This type of fracture falls under Class IIIA of the Gustilo Anderson classification.

Related Pearl: Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fracture

Gustilo-Anderson's classification for open injuries    
Type Wound Level of contamination Soft tissue injury Bone injury
I <1 cm Clean Minimal Simple, minimal comminution
II >1 cm Moderate Moderate; some muscle damage Moderate comminution
IIIA usually >10 cm High Severe with crushing Usually comminuted; soft tissue coverage of bone possible
IIIB usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery
IIIC usually >10 cm High Very severe loss of cover; vascular injury requiring repair Bone cover poor; usually requires soft tissue reconstructive surgery


Management according to Gustilo-Anderson's classification:

Types Methods of fixation
Grade  I                                A technique that is suitable for closed fracture management i.e, debridement and internal fixation by intramedullary nail and plate  
Grade II, IIIA

Within 6hr same as grade I and after 6hr same as IIIB, IIIC
Grade IIIB, IIIC

Debridement and external fixation

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumour of the diaphysis?
questions.solution: Adamantinoma is a tumour of the diaphysis. It is a rare, low-grade malignant tumour classically involving the tibial diaphysis in up to 90% of cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Modified Kocher’s criteria for septic arthritis.
questions.solution:
CRP> 2.0 mg/L is a part of the modified kocher’s criteria for the diagnosis of septic arthritis.

Criterion Value
Fever >38.5 °C
WBC >12000 cells/µL
ESR >40 mm/h
CRP >2.0 mg/L
Weight-bearing Complete inability

questions.text: Primary bone tumours are most commonly found in ?
questions.solution:
The most common site for bone tumours is distal end of the Femur.

More than 60% of the tumours arise from long bones of the lower limb.

The order of occurrence goes as follows:

Distal femur> Pelvis> Proximal Tibia> Proximal femur> Proximal Humerus.

Shoulder girdle is the least common site.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought with gradually progressive pain below his left knee over the past 6 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction. This is suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie’s abscess is a subacute variant of osteomyelitis with a milder presentation. It occurs when organisms of low virulence infect an immunocompetent host. The abscess is walled off by the thickening of the surrounding bone trabeculae. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur.

Patients present with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and it is managed by antibiotics and curettage. The following x-ray and MRI images show Brodie's abscess of the radius in a patient.

Option B: Sclerosing osteomyelitis of Garre appears as a markedly sclerotic lesion with extensive periosteal reaction.

Option C: Chronic osteomyelitis is diagnosed by the presence of sequestrum, involucrum, and cloacae. 

Option D: Osteoclastoma commonly occurs between 20-40 years of age and is unlikely in children. On a radiograph, it appears as a lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction with a soap bubble appearance.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Usual Joints affected

Disease Joint
Gout MTP of great toe
Pseudogout Knee
Rheumatoid arthritis Metacarpophalangeal joint
Ankylosing spondylitis Sacro-iliac joint
Septic arthritis Knee
Syphilitic arthritis Knee
Gonococcal arthritis Knee
Diabetic Charcot joint Foot joint(midtarsal)
Senile osteoporosis Vertebra
Paget's disease
 Pelvis > Femur >Skull >Tibia
Osteochondritis dissecans Knee >Elbow
(Most common cause of loose bodies in young)
Actinomycosis Mandible
Hemophilic arthritis Knee(Children-Ankle)
Acute osteomyelitis Lower end of femur(Metaphysis)
Brodie's abscess Upper end of tibia

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in non-structural scoliosis?
questions.solution:
Rotated vertebrae are seen in structural scoliosis.

Scoliosis is classified into 2 types:

  • Structural scoliosis - There is a non-correctable deformity due to vertebral rotation in the affected spinal segments 
  • Postural scoliosis (non-structural) - 
    • The deformity is secondary to a condition outside the spine
    • Seen in conditions such as:
      • Short leg: curvature disappears when the patient is made to sit)
      • Hip contracture with pelvic tilt: disappears after the disc prolapse is managed)
      • Lumbar disc prolapse (sciatic scoliosis)
    • If scoliosis is due to poor posture, the deformity disappears when the person is asked to bend forward

questions.text: The following X-rays depicts_______?
questions.solution:
The given x ray depicts Melorheostosis.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

Hand bones

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

4th & 5th

Decade

Osteochondroma

(Exostosis)

 Distal Femoral Metaphysis <18years
Osteoid osteoma Diaphysis of Femur

2nd & 3rd

decade
Osteoblastoma Posterior column of vertebra

2nd & 3rd

decade

Osteoclastoma (GCT)

 Distal femoral epiphysis

2nd -4th

Decade
Aneurysmal Bone Cyst Long bone Metaphysis <18years
Osteosarcoma Distal Femoral Metaphysis

BIMODAL

Primary- 2nd Decade Secondary-6th and 7th Decade
Ewings sarcoma Diaphysis of Femur 5-25 years
Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

 

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: A male patient presents with a painful, slow and gradual enlargement at the insertion of the Achilles tendon. It gets relieved with rest.  On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and patient image point towards the diagnosis of Haglund deformity. 

Haglund deformity refers to a large exostosis at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneal tuberosity located anterior to the Achilles tendon. 

This pre-tendinous bursitis usually is caused by chronic irritation from a shoe heel counter. Modification of shoe wear usually relieves symptoms. 

Treatment includes mainly conservative management. Surgical treatment is indicated if conservative management fails.

 

Option A) Hallux valgus (shown below) is caused due to the excessive lateral deviation of the great toe with the prominence of the head of the first metatarsal. It can be congenital or a consequence of rheumatoid arthritis or excessive usage of footwear with narrow toe space. The commonest complaints are pain over the bunion, worries about cosmesis and difficulty fitting shoes. Often there is also deformity of the lesser toes and pain in the forefoot. 

 

Option B: In plantar fasciitis, there is pain and tenderness in the sole of the foot, mostly under the heel, with standing or walking. The condition progresses gradually, without any clear incident or injury, but sometimes there is a history of sudden increase in sporting activity, or a change of footwear, sports shoes or running surface. There may be an associated tightness of the Achilles tendon. 

Option D: Tarsal coalition usually occurs in older children and teenagers where they present with a painful, rigid flat foot in which the peroneal and extensor tendons are in spasm.

questions.text: Which is the commonest site for Panner’s disease?
questions.solution:
The commonest site of panner’s disease(osteochondrosis of the elbow) is the humeral capitulum.

Osteochondrosis is defined by irregularity of the humeral capitulum on plain radiographs, shortly after the appearance of the ossific nucleus under 11 years of age, when the cells are vulnerable for ischaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the anatomy of the acetabulum?
questions.solution:
The articular surface of the acetabulum can be visualized as being supported between the limbs of an inverted “Y” of a bone.

  • The anterior column refers to the anterior half of the iliac wing that is contiguous with the pelvic brim to the superior pubic ramus, as well as the anterior wall of the acetabular articular surface.
  • The posterior column begins at the superior aspect of the greater sciatic notch and is contiguous with the greater and lesser sciatic notches inferiorly and includes the ischial tuberosity.
  • The anterior and posterior walls of the acetabulum are the components of the respective columns.

questions.text: A patient sustained a fracture as depicted in the image, following a fall from height. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
The fracture shown in the image is known as Malgaigne's fracture.

This fracture involves the pubic rami anteriorly and the sacroiliac joint (SI joint) or ilium near the SI joint on the same side posteriorly. 

Chauffeur's fracture refers to fracture of the radial styloid process in the forearm. 

Open book fracture are associated with pubic diastasis and/or a fracture of the pubic rami with a posterior pelvic disruption of the sacro-iliac joint.

Bucket handle fracture refers to a vertically orientated fracture through ipsilateral superior and inferior pubic rami with contralateral sacroiliac joint disruption.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with multiple bony swellings in her hands as seen in the image below marked 1. The X-ray of her hands is as shown in the image marked 2. Identify her condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows hemangiomas of the hand. The radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the small bones of hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification suggestive of enchondromatosis. This is suggestive of Maffucci's syndrome.

Maffucci's syndrome is characterised by enchondromatosis with hemangiomas of the overlying soft tissue.

Malignant potential of enchondromas:

  • Maffucci's syndrome has a 100% risk of turning into malignancy
  • Ollier disease has a 30% risk of turning into malignancy
  • Solitary enchondroma has a <2% risk of conversion to chondrosarcoma

The most common tumor affecting small bones of the hand is enchondroma. Ollier disease is characterized by multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas.

Melorheostosis is an uncommon mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosing bone with a characteristic dripping wax appearance a.k.a. flowing candle wax appearance. It is also known as Leri disease, 

Haemangiopericytomas are soft tissue sarcomas of vascular origin, comprised of pericytes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with Ewing's sarcoma is on chemotherapy. Which of the following is an indicator of poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Fever is one of the indicators for poor prognosis in Ewing's sarcoma.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anaemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Raised ESR
  • Male child and age 12–15 years

Histologic grade is of no prognostic significance because all Ewing's sarcomas are considered high grade.

Note: High levels of beta 2 microglobulin is an indicator of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: In a patient with acute compartment syndrome of the leg, which of the following muscles is most vulnerable to ischemia?
questions.solution:
Tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg which is most commonly involved in compartment syndrome.

Anterior compartment muscles are more prone for ischemia because they have Type 1 fibers which depend on oxidative metabolism for their energy source, compared to type 2 fibers, whose metabolism is primarily anaerobic.

The three main compartments are anterior (extensor), lateral(fibular) and posterior (flexor). The posterior compartment is divided into deep and superficial parts by the transverse intermuscular septum.

The anterior compartment, the least expansile of the three, is bounded by the deep fascia, the interosseous surfaces of the tibia and fibula, the interosseous membrane and the anterior intermuscular septum

questions.text: The normal velocity of impulse conduction in a motor nerve is _______
questions.solution: The normal nerve conduction velocity of motor nerve is 70 m/s.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen with the arm of the patient?

choices.text: Rupture of proximal tendon of biceps
Rupture of distal tendon of biceps
Rupture of the long belly of biceps

questions.solution:
In the above image biceps has balled up in the arm which is due to rupture of the biceps tendon.

Proximal biceps tendon make up 90-97% of all biceps ruptures and almost exclusively involve the tendon of the long head.

questions.text: Which of the following does not lead to ARDS(Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) at the blood-lung interface?

choices.text: Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture

questions.solution:
Pneumonia leads to ARDS at the air–lung interface.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a clinical syndrome of severe dyspnea of rapid onset, hypoxemia and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Chest radiograph shows Bilateral alveolar interstitial infiltrates.

Causes of ARDS at Air-lung interface:

  • Aspiration
  • Toxic gas or smoke inhalation
  • Near-drowning
  • Pneumonia
  • Pulmonary contusion

Causes of ARDS at Blood-lung interface:

  • Sepsis
  • Transfusion-related lung injury
  • Pancreatitis
  • Fat embolism
  • Thromboembolism

 

The following X-ray shows Bilateral alveolar infiltrates as seen in ARDS:

questions.text: Trapeziectomy is done in which of the following deformities?

choices.text: Boutonnière deformity with CMC joint failure

questions.solution:
Trapeziectomy is done for Boutonnière deformity with CMC joint failure and for severe swan-neck deformity.

Other options:

  • Arthritis mutilans – Arthrodesis with interposition bone graft is done.
  • Game keepers thumb – Ligament reconstruction or MCP joint fusion
  • Ruptured FPL –If painful: tendon graft or IP fusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding features of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Macrocytic anemia is the most common hematological feature
Felty’s syndrome occurs early in the course of the disease
ESR and CRP are decreased in most patients

questions.solution:
Just as CRP and ESR are increased as acute-phase reactants, platelet counts may also be increased as an acute-phase reactant in rheumatoid arthritis.

Normochromic normocytic anemia is the most common hematological abnormality seen in patients.  

Felty’s syndrome is the clinical triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly and RA seen in late stages of severe RA.

T- cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia occurs early in the course of RA.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard treatment of an acute Achilles tendon rupture in an athlete?
questions.solution:
• Open repair of acute Achilles tendon ruptures remains the “gold standard” of operative treatment, especially for athletic individuals, because of the historically low rate of reruptures, high rate of return to sports, and decreased complication rate with newer techniques.
  • Advocates of open repair argue that Achilles tendon injuries often result in complex obliquely oriented tears that cannot be adequately apposed and repaired with percutaneous or minimally invasive techniques.
